awd_titl_txt: Montclair State University Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The Montclair State University (MSU) Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program is recruiting, preparing, and supporting 30 new science teachers for New Jersey's high-need K-12 school districts.  The project is offering scholarships equal to the amount of New Jersey in-state tuition and fees to Biology, Chemistry, Earth Science, and Physics majors in their junior and senior years who were recruited in their freshman or as transfer students and subsequently admitted into the Teacher Education Program.  The PI team is promoting the diversification of the population of science teachers by recruiting STEM majors from three collaborating community colleges: the County College of Morris, Essex County College, and Passaic County Community College. 

The Noyce Scholars participate in a Science Career Survey Experience (SCSE) that is coordinated with university partners in local biotechnology, pharmaceutical, and manufacturing industries, as well as The Liberty Science Center, a nationally renowned science museum. The purpose of the SCSE component of the Noyce program is to cultivate a working knowledge of the how the curricular content of high school science classes is currently used in these careers, and the expectation is that these experiences will influence their teaching.

The project also advances discovery and understanding through a research program entitled Knowledge in Science Teaching (KiST).  The KiST project is studying the way in which individuals learn to teach secondary science in diverse classrooms and examining changes in science teachers' pedagogical content knowledge over the course of the teacher preparation program and through student teaching.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to produce 30 well-prepared science teachers for New Jersey's high need schools.  Since its founding over 100 years ago as The New Jersey State Normal School at Montclair, Montclair State University's teacher education program has grown and is highly ranked and respected nationally.

The project leaders were well-qualified to successfully meet this project goal.  The project leaders were Dr. Sandra Adams, an experienced biologist, science educator, and former high school biology teacher with doctoral degrees in science education and biology; Dr. Douglas Larkin, an experienced science educator and former high school physics and chemistry teacher with a doctorate in science education; and Dr. John Berger, an experienced faculty member of a chemistry department, who holds a doctorate in chemistry.  Although it took longer than anticipated we successfully prepared 33 science and mathematics teachers for New Jersey's high need schools. Of the 33 STEM teachers prepared by this project, 4 majored in biology and minored in chemistry, 14 were biology majors, 5 were chemistry majors, 2 were physics majors, and 4 majored in mathematics.

This project advanced knowledge in the recruitment and retention of science and mathematics teachers.  Recruitment was our greatest struggle.  Among the lessons learned were strategies that were successful for recruiting students to teacher education.  A component of our recruitment strategy was to recruit from neighboring community colleges.  Although some of our Noyce Scholars were community college transfers, the number was less than we expected.  Another finding was that current Scholars were very effective in recruiting new students to teacher education and to our Noyce program.  We also gained knowledge about successful strategies for retaining teachers that are transferrable to not only STEM disciplines but to other teaching fields as well. Of the 33 teachers prepared by this project, 29 (87.88%) are currently teaching and 24 (72.72%) are currently teaching in a high needs-school in New Jersey.  This knowledge was leveraged into the design of a new Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program at Montclair that was awarded in 2022. There are now more students underrepresented in STEM fields, including minority students and students from low socioeconomic backgrounds, being taught by highly qualified teachers with excellent preparation in their content fields and in pedagogy (how to teach).

 


Last Modified: 09/01/2023
Modified by: Sandra D Adams
